meanings.definition: Alter or manipulate (data, figures, etc.) in order to deceive or mislead.
meanings.sent1: She fudged the numbers to make it seem like she had more money.
meanings.sent2: He always fudged his expenses to get more reimbursement.
meanings.sent3: The student fudged the results of the experiment to impress the teacher.
meanings.sent4: The politician fudged his promises, leaving the voters disappointed.
meanings.sent5: The detective uncovered how the criminal fudged the evidence to avoid suspicion.

meanings.definition: To improvise or make do with what is available.
meanings.sent1: When the recipe called for milk, she fudged and used water instead.
meanings.sent2: He had to fudge a solution using only the tools he had in his backpack.
meanings.sent3: In a pinch, she fudged a makeshift tent out of blankets and chairs.
meanings.sent4: The team had to fudge a plan on the spot when their original strategy failed.
meanings.sent5: The actor had to fudge his lines when he forgot the script during the play.

meanings.definition: To fail to perform as expected or promised.
meanings.sent1: The car fudged when he tried to start it in the cold weather.
meanings.sent2: She fudged during the presentation and couldn't remember her key points.
meanings.sent3: The robot fudged its dance routine, causing laughter among the audience.
meanings.sent4: The singer fudged the high note, disappointing her fans.
meanings.sent5: The athlete fudged at the crucial moment, costing his team the victory.
